data.title: The New York Times
data.meta_description: Jessica Grose is an Opinion writer for The Times, covering family, religion, education, culture and the way we live now.
data.text:
Jessica Grose

I’m an Opinion writer for The New York Times.

What I Cover

I cover family, religion, education and culture. I am particularly interested in finding fresh angles on major social changes, like why Americans are moving away from organized religion, and why the birthrate has fallen around the world. I love doing surveys, and I find that hearing from Times readers about the issues that are dear to their hearts is one of my favorite parts of the job.

My Background

I have been covering family, policy and pop culture at many publications including Slate, New York Magazine and Jezebel since I graduated from Brown University in 2004. I joined the Times as the editor of their parenting product in 2018, and I moved to the Opinion section in 2021.

I am also the author of “Screaming on The Inside: The Unsustainability of American Motherhood,” and two novels “Soulmates” and “Sad Desk Salad.” I was the founding editor of Lenny, the email newsletter and website. I was named a Glamour “Game Changer” in 2020 for my coverage of parenting during the pandemic.

I grew up in Irvington, N.Y., and I remember nerding out over Entertainment Weekly, Sassy, Mirabella and other magazines in their ’90s heyday — I would be so excited to check the mailbox. I started writing for my high school newspaper, and I eventually became the editor. In college, I was an arts editor at The Indy, Brown’s independent weekly. I thought I would be a rock critic (my first job out of undergrad was at Spin) but I realized pretty quickly that I wanted to widen my lens to many more subjects.

I live with my husband and two kids in Brooklyn.

Journalistic Ethics

As a Times journalist I am committed to upholding the standards of integrity outlined in our Ethical Journalism Handbook. Though I am an opinion writer, my stories are always reported and rigorously fact-checked (our department’s fact checkers are top tier, I trust them with my life).
